Timeline

In 2007, viewers up and down the country were treated to a lavish retelling of King Henry VIII's rule, filled with scandal, conflict, and no small number of raunchy scenes.

The show ran for four seasons, telling the tale of Henry's famous wives and the dissolution of the monasteries.

Filmed mostly in Ireland, the show was renewed for a fourth and final time in 2009 and the final episode aired in 2010.

For more celebrity and TV stories, click here.

In the 15 years since the first series launched, we take a look at where Henry and his royal subjects are now.

From Superman to Game of Thrones, some of these stars have enjoyed a great deal of success - perhaps even befitting of a king.

Jonathan Rhys Meyers

(Image: ITV)

Jonathan Rhys Meyers blew fans away in his role as King Henry VIII, bringing an unpredictable and sexy energy to the royal court.

The Irish star, now 44, went on to star in a number of other high profile shows including NBC's Dracula and the History Channel's Vikings, as well as film roles including 2013's The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones, and 2015's Stonewall.

As well as being voted as the 44th greatest Irish film actor in 2020, Rhys Meyers has also gone on to feature as the face of a number of Hugo Boss campaigns.

Unlike his royal counterpart King Henry, Jonathan has just the one wife and the pair share a son together.

Maria Doyle Kennedy

Maria Doyle Kennedy gave an outstanding portrayal of Henry's first wife, Catherine of Aragon in The Tudors and it may shock you to learn that the star is now 57 years old!

In her time since the show, Maria has starred in a number of feature films, including Tara Road, Albert Nobbs, Jupiter Ascending, Sing Street and The Conjuring 2.

Like Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Maria was included in the 2020 list of Ireland's greatest film actors, being ranked 46th.

As well as her acting, Maria Doyle Kennedy has released eleven musical albums and fourteen singles.

Henry Cavill

(Image: Getty)

Henry Cavill played Charles Brandon, 1st Duke of Sussex and best friend to King Henry. A bit of a womaniser, Charles was always getting himself into trouble and was routinely banished from court.

Not that being banished caused him any problems...

Now 38, Henry Cavill is known around the world for a different role - that of Superman in the Man of Steel franchise.

Other notable roles for the dashingly handsome Cavill are as Geralt of Rivia in Netflix's The Witcher and Sherlock Holmes in Enola Holmes, starring Millie Bobby Brown.

Did you spot Henry out in Hull when they were filming in the Old Town?

Natalie Dormer

(Image: Mirror)

Natalie Dormer gave an unforgettable turn as Henry's second wife Anne Boleyn, drawing the King's eye and ending both his first marriage and the Pope's jurisdiction in England in the process.

Now 39, Natalie Dormer is perhaps better known for her appearance in another TV series concerning kings and queens.

Between 2012 and 2016, Natalie starred as Margaery Tyrell in the HBO mega-series Game of Thrones, earning herself further acclaim and cementing her reputation as a fantastic period actor.

Other notable roles include parts in The Hunger Games films and the mini series Penny Dreadful: City of Angels.

Sam Neill

(Image: BBC)

Sam Neill gave a brilliant performance as the cunning Cardinal Wolsey, who sought to get King Henry his divorce while holding onto his own position of power within the kingdom.

Since then, many will recognise Sam Neill from his role in the first season of Peaky Blinders where he played Tommy Shelby's nemesis, the crafty Inspector Campbell who sought to clean up the streets of Birmingham.

Other roles include parts in Alcatraz, Crusoe, Happy Town, and even some voice acting in Rick and Morty.

Neill is now 74 and lives in New Zealand with his family. He has three children and one stepchild.

Jeremy Northam

Jeremy Northam played the role of Sir Thomas More, King Henry's trusted friend and councillor. More became a tormented character when Henry's desire for a divorce began to clash with his religious beliefs.

In the time since appearing on The Tudors, Northam has appeared in a range of other dramatic roles, and it would seem that he just cannot keep away from royalty...

From 2016 to 2017, Jeremy starred as Anthony Eden in the hit Netflix series, The Crown.

Jeremy is now 60 years old, meaning he has outlived Sir Thomas by quite some distance!

James Frain

(Image: Internet Unknown)

James Frain played the scheming and talented Thomas Cromwell, who rose from obscurity to be one of the most powerful men in King Henry's court.

Since The Tudors, James Frain has gone on to enjoy a hugely successful acting career, including roles in HBO's vampire drama True Blood and the BBC's Orphan Black.

After having a taste of royalty, Frain played Warwick the Kingmaker in 2013's The White Queen.

Since 2017, James has played Spock's dad Sarek in Star Trek Discovery.

Actress Lucy Akhurst was widely known for her presence on the silver screen. At the beginning of her acting career, Akhurst landed roles in action flicks like the Val Kilmer film "The Saint" (1997). She had an early role on the television special "The Cinder Path" (PBS, 1994-95). She worked in television in her early acting career as well, including a part on "Midsomer Murders" (ITV 1, 1996). She also landed a role in the miniseries "Longitude" (1999-2000). More recently, she earned a role in the action film "Circus" (2000) with John Hannah. She also worked in television around this time, including a part on "Monarch of the Glen" (BBC Scotland, 1999-2006). She also was featured in the TV movie "Eroica" (2003-04). Most recently, Akhurst acted on "Spotless" (Esquire Network, 2015-).

Wikipedia has listed various inaccuracies as character names, relationships, historical costume, physical appearance and the timing of events.

As creator Hirst noted, "Showtime commissioned me to write an entertainment, a soap opera, and not history ... And we wanted people to watch it." He added that some changes were made for production considerations and some to avoid viewer confusion, and that "any confusion created by the changes is outweighed by the interest the series may inspire in the period and its figures."

Some listed errors from Wikipedia are:

Historically, Cardinal Wolsey died of an unspecified illness in Leicester in 1530

The character of Henry's sister, called "Princess Margaret" in the series, is actually a composite of his two sisters: the life events of his younger sister, Princess Mary Tudor, coupled with the name of his elder sister, Margaret Tudor.

The king's natural son Henry Fitzroy was shown to be born near the beginning of the series and dying at a very young age from the sweating sickness. In fact, he lived until 1536, long enough to marry the only daughter of Anne Boleyn's uncle Thomas Howard, Duke of Norfolk, and be a witness to Anne Boleyn's execution.

Henry's daughter Mary is shown to be openly hostile towards Catherine Parr having discovered her Protestant view. Mary didn't fall out with Catherine until after Henry's death, when the Queen hastily married Thomas Seymour.

And many more inaccuracies are there.

Also, from www.thetudorswiki.com:

More than 400 years after their era ended, the Tudors are everywhere, striding across stages and swaggering onto screens, haunting our politics, and even slipping into our wardrobes by way of statement sleeves and Anne Boleyn necklines. The Duchess of Cambridge has been sporting pearl-studded velvet headbands, and Boleyn and her fellow wives are now strutting their stuff on both Broadway and the West End in Six, a musical by Lucy Moss and Toby Marlow that features an electronica remix of Greensleeves.

More like this:

- What are fiction’s best first lines?

Nowhere is the dynasty’s pull felt more forcefully than in literature – from fiction to non-fiction, high-brow to low, the Tudor reign is apparently unshakeable. And towering above all those portly Henrys and jewel-encrusted wives is one man: Hilary Mantel’s Thomas Cromwell, whose final outing looks set to become the publishing event of the year.

Lucy Akhurst (b. 18 November 1975 in London ) is an English actress who has been working mainly in television since the 1990s. She starred alongside Neil Morrisey in " Vanishing Man " and then came to prominence in a lead role in 1999's ITV seven-part drama "Wonderful You".

She appeared as Tim's ( Simon Pegg 's) girlfriend for 4 episodes of UK comedy " Spaced " and also guest-starred as a zombie in Simon Pegg and Edgar Wright 's critically acclaimed " Shaun of the Dead ".

She also appeared in the 2004 series of the BBC 's " Monarch of the Glen ".

More recently she wrote, produced and starred in " Every Seven Years " a short film that has won several awards.

Lucy Akhurst (born 18 November 1970) is an English actress, writer and director who has been working mainly in television since the 1990s. She starred alongside Neil Morrissey in The Vanishing Man and then came to prominence in a lead role in 1999's ITV seven-part drama Wonderful You.

She appeared as Tim's (Simon Pegg) girlfriend for four episodes of UK comedy Spaced and also guest-starred as a zombie in Simon Pegg and Edgar Wright's comedy film Shaun of the Dead.

She also appeared in the 2004 series of the BBC's Monarch of the Glen.

More recently she wrote, produced and starred in Every Seven Years a short film that has won several awards. She also directed, co-produced and had a small part in the independent British film , written, co-produced by and starring her husband Chaz Oldham.[1] [2]

Akhurst provided the voiceovers for EastEnders in March 2009 for the Mitchell family storyline.

Notes and References

Lucy Akhurst (born 18 November 1975, in London) is an English actress, writer and director who has been working mainly in television since the 1990s. She starred alongside Neil Morrissey in The Vanishing Man and then came to prominence in a lead role in 1999's ITV seven-part drama Wonderful You.

She appeared as Tim's (Simon Pegg) girlfriend for four episodes of UK comedy Spaced and also guest-starred as a zombie in Simon Pegg and Edgar Wright's comedy film Shaun of the Dead.

She also appeared in the 2004 series of the BBC's Monarch of the Glen.

More recently she wrote, produced and starred in Every Seven Years a short film that has won several awards. She also directed, co-produced and had a small part in the independent British film Morris: A Life with Bells On, written, co-produced by and starring her husband Chaz Oldham. She wrote an article in The Daily Mail about her experiences in making the film.

Akhurst provided the voiceovers for EastEnders in March 2009 for the Mitchell family storyline.

A decade after scripting the Oscar-nominated 1998 film Elizabeth, screenwriter Michael Hirst turned his attention to another English monarch for the hit drama The Tudors.

Premiering on April 1, 2007, as Showtime’s biggest debut in three years, The Tudors dramatized the reign of King Henry VIII, retelling a historical saga of murder and intrigue with creative liberties aplenty. (“Showtime commissioned me to write an entertainment, a soap opera, and not history,” Hirst told The New York Times the following year. “And we wanted people to watch it.”)

Jonathan Rhys Meyers played that infamous king, and other familiar faces filled the Tudors cast, too, including Natalie Dormer, Sarah Bolger, and Henry Cavill. As the show hits its 15th anniversary, we’re checking in on the careers of 10 of its alums.

And these are just the longest-running cast members! The Tudors call sheet also included Jurassic Park’s Sam Neill, Nip/Tuck’s Joely Richardson, Downton Abbey’s Allen Leech, and Oscar winner Peter O’Toole, among many other stars of TV and film.

In any event, scroll down to see where you’ve seen 10 Tudors alum on screen recently.
